content: The "Fair Raises for Seniors Act" may be cited as the Act. It includes provisions related to the Consumer Price Index for elderly consumers. The "Fair Raises for Seniors Act" includes provisions for the creation of the Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers (CPI-E) by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This index will track the average change in prices paid by individuals aged 62 and older in the United States for a range of consumer goods and services. The Bureau will increase the number of elderly individuals sampled compared to the Consumer Price Index for Urban Wage Earners and Clerical Workers (CPI-W) and establish samples of market-based items and stores. The "Fair Raises for Seniors Act" authorizes the creation of the Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers (CPI-E) by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. This index will track price changes for individuals aged 62 and older, focusing on their unique purchasing patterns, medical care costs, and usage of prescription drugs. Appropriations are authorized for implementation, and the section will be effective starting from July 31 of the calendar year following the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. COMPUTATION OF COST-OF-LIVING INCREASES. Section 215(i) of the Social Security Act is amended to adjust monthly insurance benefits for individuals aged 62 and older based on the Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers. This adjustment applies to primary insurance amounts under sections 227 and 228. Section 215(i) of the Social Security Act is amended to adjust monthly insurance benefits for individuals aged 62 and older based on the Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers. This adjustment applies to primary insurance amounts under sections 227 and 228, with additional amendments for adjustments after the individual attains age 62. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall apply to cost-of-living computations for individuals aged 62 and older under the Social Security Act, effective for quarters ending on or after September 30 of the second calendar year following the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Amends section 3121(a) of the Internal Revenue Code to apply payroll tax on remuneration up to $250,000. Effective for remuneration paid after December 31, 2014. Tax on net earnings from self-employment up to contribution and benefit base and more than $250,000. Tax on net earnings from self-employment exceeding the contribution and benefit base, minus wages paid to the individual during the taxable year. The text chunk discusses the phaseout of tax on net earnings from self-employment exceeding the contribution and benefit base, minus wages paid to the individual during the taxable year. It specifies the calculation formula and conditions for the phaseout. The amendments apply to taxable years starting when the contribution and benefit base is under $250,000. Effective December 31, 2014, the changes affect self-employment earnings and remuneration. SEC. 6. INCLUSION OF SURPLUS EARNINGS FOR BENEFIT DETERMINATIONS. The amendment includes the inclusion of surplus average indexed monthly earnings in determining primary insurance amounts under the Social Security Act. It also introduces the concept of Basic AIME and Surplus AIME. The amendment introduces the concept of Basic AIME and Surplus AIME in determining primary insurance amounts under the Social Security Act. It includes adjustments to subparagraphs and clauses within the Act. The amendment introduces the calculation of an individual's surplus average indexed monthly earnings based on their total surplus earnings divided by the number of months in benefit computation years. Surplus earnings are defined as wages and self-employment income exceeding the contribution and benefit base for the year. The amendment modifies Section 215(b) of the Act to include the calculation of surplus average indexed monthly earnings, based on total surplus earnings divided by the number of months in benefit computation years. Surplus earnings are defined as income exceeding the contribution and benefit base for the year. The amendment includes calculating surplus average indexed monthly earnings by multiplying an individual's surplus earnings for a benefit computation year by a specific quotient. Conforming amendments also adjust references to average indexed monthly earnings in related sections of the Act. The amendments made by this section apply to individuals who become eligible for old-age or disability insurance benefits under title II of the Social Security Act after 2014.
